meta_data.title: Commentary with The Chrises // An Atheist’s View Part 2

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner and I'm joined by Chris Sherrod and Chris Legg. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to another episode of the Reconstructed Faith podcast. And of course, as a kid, we don't know which one that is, is that parent being abusive or are they taking us to the dentist and it feels the same to us when we're a child. So as we grow up, we learn to, you know, we, we ought to have a podcast about this where we deconstruct our understandings and try to reconstruct what really is there so that we can understand what is a father, what is a God, what would it, is there a way to understand this whole hardening of Pharaoh's heart that would makes more sense given that there is a God. Anyway, I just, I loved the analogy because it, I think it is actually a great picture of what many people are doing right now. Yeah. Even in, you mentioned it just briefly, but even the idea that was God saving some of these Canaanite kids from being slaughtered anyways, their own parents, because that's what, I mean, some of these Canaanites worship, Molech and we're going to be, and so God's stopping some big evil, awful thing. But then again, you're upset with like, well, if he didn't do anything, I'm upset. But then when he does something, I'm upset. He just didn't do it the way I wanted. There's so many pankov interviews that I did over the years where one of the questions is when, when you become a parent, one day, is there anything you might do differently? And for people who don't know, this is, this is interviews with college students. Yeah. The college students could be on staff. I cannot tell you how many times the answer was, you know, I used to think there were so many things I was going to do differently. And now looking back, right, I probably am going to do the exact same thing. And that's just, that's exactly what you're saying is that at the time, you don't understand, you don't know why you don't agree. And is it possible, even with the way we understand God, that there is a really good reason that we can't handle or grasp? I feel like that happens a lot of times with parents and kids or teenagers when they've got their plan, why can't I do that? And you're like, okay, you're not considering, you know, we've got to go over here, and we got this, and we still got to put gas in the car, and we've got to, it's not just your one plan that you're upset about, it's like you're not considering the bigger picture. So again, I think that people are, can be mad at God because he didn't, or they don't understand, but that, like you said, Chris, doesn't prove that he doesn't exist. And it really could be that you just don't understand, or you're only wanting him to be the God who always says yes, because your concept of God is, he's a kindly grandfather in the sky that just wants everybody to have a good day. And that's something, God, that you find in the Bible. And I've said this before, but I love the way Tim Keller says to people, describe to me the God you don't believe in, the God that you've rejected, I might not believe in him either. Right. So yeah. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us. Trust God. Search for answers.

morality, I mean what that means is it's almost like what Chris was talking about before about
love and feelings and things like that, that everything's going to get reduced to just either
might makes right, or this is just personal preference, or you're just going to end up
talking about instead of morality, it's legality. Like it's just, is it legal? That's what makes
something right or wrong. Yeah. He actually defined murder incorrectly. And again, I wasn't
in the place to interrupt, but murder being the illegal taking of human life. I was like, no,
that's, that would not be the correct definition of murder. It's not an, it's not murder is not
merely a legal concept. Anyway, sorry, go ahead. That was, that struck me as that in that moment.
No, yeah. That's all my thoughts were. I mean, initially we can talk more about morality later,
but it's just, you're going to always, it's, it's you, you're going to have no ground for saying
something is absolutely right or wrong. Right. If there's no God, it's going to break down.
So it eventually is, it's going to be either genetic wiring, which then you have no excuse
to say anything to hold anybody accountable. Like you just can't help it. It's in your DNA.
But it, and it, it's just going to make things like might mix, right. Who gets to decide what
is best for overall society? Cause if it's just what's the majority agree that this is good,
then can the majority ever be wrong? Yeah. Like would we say in our country,
the majority has ever been wrong. It's like, yeah, all the time. Yeah, exactly. So it, without
an objective standard that's outside of all of us, it's really going to come down to
might makes right, or who are you? Everything's going to be just, who are you to say? And I think
we've moved in our country from what is asking what is right to asking what is right for me
to now the big thing is I have a right. Everything is all the radical autonomy. Right. I have a right
for everything. Okay. Well, let me, since we'll, we'll, we'll hit more of the morality thing.
Cause he's going to, we're going to impact that more in the last segment. Yes. We'll, yeah. We'll
postpone that one for the next response. One other thing I wanted to ask you about
specifically Chris, cause you said you wanted, and both of you can comment on it.
It was an interesting commentary that David had when he's talking about people turning away from
atheism, um, against Christianity. And the quote was something around the vast majority of people
who become atheists. It's a bit like turning against a father who is abusive. Right. And so,
I think that is a, is there, is there a, what would you say to that?
Love about that analogy. And again, I was, it was interesting. I was actually talking with your
sister, Lana some this morning about this, but it is, it is wild to consider from a purely
sociological perspective, the three men who are sitting in that room, having the conversation,
um, that we had talked about, are you a question asker or not? Who gave you the freedom to ask
questions or not? Um, you know, did you just do kind of believe what you were told to believe
or not? Were you encouraged that you ought to do that or not? And, and so it was intriguing to me
that, that David, I think very intuitively engaged with God as an abusive, abusive father. Um, and so,
but what I, what I love about that analogy is I actually, I actually think he is very right
about that. I think he is very, especially in modern times that there is a father and he,
he doesn't approve of your gay friends activities or there is a father and he doesn't approve of
your boyfriend or your girlfriend. There is a father and he doesn't approve of some life
decision you're going to make. Now, what's wild is how often they're wrong that they're, that they're
wrong about what the father approves of or doesn't approve of. But that is their assumption. Notice
though, that that father exists. And so to say, I walk away from God the way I'd walk away from
an abusive father. So what you're, what David is saying is because he abused my mom one too many
times, because he used our money to buy alcohol one too many times, I am now declaring that he
doesn't exist and that's not healthy. The healthy attitude is to say, I need to get a different
concept for father. The healthy concept is I need to build something different than this, that the
image I have of father stinks. And I would agree that the version of God that David grew up with
stinks and, and the, what he was taught as a child is not good. Um, and I think that's true for all
of us to one degree or another, that some of the things we learned about God weren't right or
weren't good, or we weren't mature enough to know how to engage with it. And certainly a good father
does things like take us to the dentist that may make us really mad and may make us feel rejected
or hurt. Um, or we may not understand their motives or for why they did something in, and that can do
it. Um, or on earth, our father may actually have been terrible. Um, many people have abusive,
horrible horrific fathers. And the idea of saying a father who acts like this, I don't want them to
be my father. I think it's completely understandable and acceptable. Um, a father, but, but so the
question is always, is this my father being abusive or is this my father trying to help a mentally ill
wife or is this my father taking me to the dentist, which I really hate, or is this my father,
you know, working too much because I don't understand how much the, my medicine costs.
Like all of those are options when you're talking about an actual father,
but in all of them, there is a father and the, the, to say there is a God and I'm just so mad at how
he treated the Canaanites and there is a God and I'm just so, I just do not understand why he thinks
homosexual behavior is sin. I don't get it. I don't agree with him. I think he's off. Okay.
So either that God is wrong and often and doesn't understand what he should understand about
homosexual behavior with humans for just as an example, this is just, there's such a common one
nowadays or to, I can't live with my boyfriend or girlfriend or whatever pick picket, or is that a
God who's saying, listen, that's the, that's the pointy end of that revolver. Don't point it at
yourself and pull the trigger thing because I know how revolvers work. And of course, as a kid,
we don't know which one that is, is that parent being abusive or are they taking us to the dentist
and it feels the same to us when we're a child. So as we grow up, we learn to, you know, we, we
ought to have a podcast about this where we deconstruct our understandings and try to reconstruct
what really is there so that we can understand what is a father, what is a God, what would it,
is there a way to understand this whole hardening of Pharaoh's heart
that would makes more sense given that there is a God. Anyway, I just, I loved the analogy because
it, I think it is actually a great picture of what many people are doing right now.
Yeah. Even in, you mentioned it just briefly, but even the idea that
was God saving some of these Canaanite kids from being slaughtered anyways,
their own parents, because that's what, I mean, some of these Canaanites worship,
Molech and we're going to be, and so God's stopping some big evil, awful thing.
But then again, you're upset with like, well, if he didn't do anything, I'm upset. But then when
he does something, I'm upset. He just didn't do it the way I wanted. There's so many pankov
interviews that I did over the years where one of the questions is when, when you become a parent,
one day, is there anything you might do differently? And for people who don't know, this is,
this is interviews with college students. Yeah. The college students could be on staff.
I cannot tell you how many times the answer was, you know, I used to think there were so many
things I was going to do differently. And now looking back, right, I probably am going to do
the exact same thing. And that's just, that's exactly what you're saying is that at the time,
you don't understand, you don't know why you don't agree. And is it possible, even with the way we
understand God, that there is a really good reason that we can't handle or grasp? And if your answer
is no, no, I always never, you start to go, well, that's, that's crazy to think if there's really a
God, it's very, very likely that there are things that he could never even explain to you because
you wouldn't get where you don't understand, or there's a way bigger picture, there's a lot of
more moving parts that you just haven't factored that in. I feel like that happens a lot of times
with parents and kids or teenagers when they've got their plan, why can't I do that? And you're
like, okay, you're not considering, you know, we've got to go over here, and we got this, and we still
got to put gas in the car, and we've got to, it's not just your one plan that you're upset about,
it's like you're not considering the bigger picture. So again, I think that people are,
can be mad at God because he didn't, or they don't understand, but that, like you said,
Chris, doesn't prove that he doesn't exist. And it really could be that you just don't understand,
or you're only wanting him to be the God who always says yes, because your concept of God is,
he's a kindly grandfather in the sky that just wants everybody to have a good day.
And that's something, God, that you find in the Bible. And I've said this before,
but I love the way Tim Keller says to people, describe to me the God you don't believe in,
the God that you've rejected, I might not believe in him either.
Right.
So yeah.
Yeah, that's great. Well, thank you guys for hitting on this.
Absolutely.
We'll get into the divine hiddenness thing.
Exactly. That's what I was going to say. We're going to talk a lot more about divine hiddenness
and the morality piece. That'll be coming after the third and final session that we had with David
Smalley. If there was any part of this that you're like, oh man, I really wish they could have unpacked
some of this. Something maybe triggered you. Please feel free to shoot us an email, shoot me
an email info at southspring.org with that question. It would be helpful if you kind of
gave me the timestamp on the Smalley section that you're like, hey, I would really love this
to be addressed and we can look at that. So yeah, we'll pick this up in the next episode.
Thanks guys for listening.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
